subject: Make log services use parameter delegation
commitMessage:
Make log services use parameter delegation

The commit prior to this one added support for delegation of $expand and
$only query param types;  This commit adds support for delegation of top
and skip (which we already have a few handlers for) and moves them to
the new style.

Note, this makes top and skip query params NOT below the
insecure-enable-redfish-query.  top and skip have existed for a while,
and are unlikely to have security issues, as they're relatively simple
transforms.

Tested:

curl --insecure --user root:0penBmc  https://192.168.7.2/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/LogServices/Journal/Entries\?\$top\=3\&\$skip\=0

With varying $top between 1-5 and $skip between 0-5 gave the expected
number of log results.

Unit tests pass.

Signed-off-by: Ed Tanous <edtanous@google.com>
Change-Id: Ia213a5e929c40579825eaf251e4b9159bc84c802

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as c937d2bfefa3ff91b7175d9684f99712ec9b88e5
Pretty sure this can be unit tested easily. Consider adding them?

Unit tests are added in the next commit.   The prototypes of these change in the next commit, and in a way that makes them a lot easier to test so it didn't make a ton of sense to write some really complex tests (constructing Response and Request objects) just to delete them in the next commit.

Happy to restructure if there's a way that makes these easier to review.
Ack
Some nits.
keep consistent with previous enum and explicitly set the underlying type?
Because this is a return code, and not used as part of a structure that's copied, we generally will prefer letting the compiler pick here, which will pick int, which in theory is more efficient.
seems like not following OpenBMC naming convention
ACK.  I forgot we even had a naming convention for that.
is this different than "constexpr uint64_t"?

I've never understood if constexpr implies const or not.  Maybe it does?, but I remember it mattering in some old context (that I can't remember).

Happy to change it so long as it compiles.

AFAIK, it's the same in this case. 

https://godbolt.org/z/qasbs8McG

I'm sure the compiler generates the same code in either case, that's less what I'm worried about:

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50609668/is-const-constexpr-on-variables-redundant

Seems to say that it matters if you take pointers to things, because the pointer needs to be const as well.  In this case, I'm happy to change this, because I don't think it hits that case.
Done
Where does this upper limit come from?

Is zero illegal?

From the spec, "Minimum value is 0 , though a value of 0 returns an empty set of members."
This was copied from the old $top code, so it had a bug, but yes, you're correct, zero is legal.

This is what the old top code picked, and I'm pretty sure it was arbitrary (Jason can weigh in if he remembers why it was picked).

I suspect this is something we'll need to evaluate and tune, but 1000 seems like a reasonable default for most of our larger collections.
Fixed.
Ack
I missed this in the previous change, but can this be constexpr? That could save an allocation, right?

Could it be constexpr, maybe, but that imposes that QueryCapabilities always be constexpr constructible, so we don't necessarily want to do that.

I'm pretty sure constexpr or not these will generate the same code, so this isn't really the level of change that I would generally enforce.

With all that said, if there's a good reason to do that, I'm happy to make the change, I'm just not seeing what it would improve.  Does making this contexpr actually generate different code?

https://godbolt.org/z/TjhsqYbqE

I tried, codes are similar. I don't know if that will make a big difference. And yeah, I agree, when we have std::unordered_set introduced into QueryCapabilities, it won't be constexpr constructible
nit: is this missing a word? and "something" only;
"only" in this case is the name of a filter query param type, so no, there's not a word missing.  Not sure how I could phrase that to be less confusing....

Ah. That's a little confusing haha

You could just highlight the filter query param types like, "expand" and "only", then "top" and "skip" in the next sentence for clarity

I change them to the names with $ so hopefully that's better.

Done.

nit: not sure if this is really enforced much, but I see in the C++ style guide that the enum members should be lowerCamelCase - https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#constants

Interesting..... I thought it was upper camel.....  For the moment, all of bmcweb is upper camel for enum class members, so in this case consistency is better than having one that follows the standard, although I'll stick it on my list to figure out the tidy rule for it and get it fixed across the whole codebase.

Fair enough, I actually stumbled across this review because I was looking for examples of enum being lowerCamelCase (as I was writing my own enum following the guide but I haven't seen many lowerCamelCase enums in my reviews much - I've even seen all caps enums)
There's a bunch more tidy rules I need to go turn on.  What we have is pretty minimal (as you're seeing).
Just realized that this might break stuff for people that don't have the new query param stuff set.
Oh, yes, any ideas how to resolve it?
I need to look at it
This is resolved on the latest patchset.
When query parameter is not enabled, this will always be a default struct, which means no parameters are delegated, then this code is wrong since $top and $skip are not handled at all.

Can you elaborate a little on what you mean?  I'm assuming "default struct" means "default constructed struct with default parameters"?

top defaults to size_t::max(), and skip defaults to 0, so even with default arguments, we should still get the desired effect.

> $top and $skip are not handled at all.

I also don't understand this statement.  Top and skip are handled on line 1266 and 1282.

> When redifsh-query is turned off, the returned |delegatedQuery| struct is basically the following
> 
> ```
> struct Query
> {
>     // Only
>     bool isOnly = false;
>     // Expand
>     uint8_t expandLevel = 0;
>     ExpandType expandType = ExpandType::None;
> 
>     // Skip
>     size_t skip = 0;
> 
>     // Top
>     size_t top = std::numeric_limits<size_t>::max();
> };
> ```
> Because we returned early.
> https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/54417b02efbfe896d6ef442cfc6a721314aac3f8/redfish-core/include/query.hpp#L35
> 
> then the codes here will assume don't skip any entry and return all entry (top==max), right?
> 
> Finally the async response just closed without running a new completion handler at https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/54417b02efbfe896d6ef442cfc6a721314aac3f8/redfish-core/include/query.hpp#L53.
> 
> As a result, we just ignore $top and $skip in this request. Is that the indented behavior when redifsh-query is off?


Gotcha, yes, this is what I was pointing out in the other comment.  If query params are disabled, and we merge this code, the existing top implementations will break.  I suspect we need to find a solution where $top and $skip are not covered by that check.  I"m looking into it.
Done
Added commit message comments to fix the bug.  Top and skip are no longer handled as part of the query param option.
LGTM. The previous concern was resolved.
